thread.title: Hays bald eagles unlikely to be disturbed by controlled explosion near rail line
thread.title_full: Hays bald eagles unlikely to be disturbed by controlled explosion near rail line

author: John Hayes / Pittsburgh Post-Gazette
title: Hays bald eagles unlikely to be disturbed by controlled explosion near rail line
text:
Hays bald eagles unlikely to be disturbed by controlled explosion near rail line February 22, 2017 12:12 PM Bob Donaldson/Post-Gazette A spokeswoman with the Audubon Society of Western Pennsylvania says work on a Norfolk Southern Railroad line should have no impact on the bald eagle pair nesting in the area. By John Hayes /   
Maintenance planned today on a Norfolk Southern Railroad line in Hays will include a controlled explosion on the steep hillside where the troubled bald eagles have rebuilt their nest. 
In an email message, Rachel Handel, communications director of the Audubon Society of Western Pennsylvania, said the birds are unlikely to be disturbed by the blast and subsequent removal of rocks and debris. 
"We have talked with Norfolk Southern and determined that this work should not have any impact on the bald eagles, as it is about a half mile to 1 mile away from the nest site," she said "Weâ€™re watching the situation." 
Since Feb. 12, when a windstorm toppled the tree that held their nest, the eagle pair have hastily constructed a new nest more than 100 yards west of the previous site and beyond camera range of the live-feed video system that has permitted views inside the nest since 2014. Based on the Hays eagles' behavior, it is believed the female has laid at least one egg. 
John Hayes: 412-263-1991, jhayes@post-gazette.com.
